Reviews.Title: Great Step Up From the T1i
Reviews.Author: Michael Pacylowski
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera as a replacement to my aging T1i. I feel that I more closely represent the target market for Canon regarding this camera, as it truly does not represent a 40D or 50D replacement in my opinion. Those users are clearly being migrated over to the 7D. As for me however, this is the ideal replacement/upgrade. You can read all about this camera and it's pros and cons, however if you do any video work at all, the articulating screen is a must, and the overall speed of the camera is perfect for a committed dad who never wants to miss a moment when the kids are on the field. I highly recommend this to users who have cut their teeth on Canon's entry level DSLRs, however for those who have not, the interface may be a bit intimidating.

Reviews.Title: Very Good - First Serious Camera - for Amateur like Myself
Reviews.Author: Mark Early
Reviews.Content: The 60D has been mostly a wonderful experience for an amateur like myself.  Using it for the first time on a vacation in Provence France.  Only one big issue so far and that might be due to operator error;  on a bright moonlit night a huge rock escarpment called out to be captured by the 60D, but I could NOT GET THE dang CAMERA to take the shot, it just utterly refused !I've shot 1300+ photos with it over the last 14 days and this was the first time it just would not allow me to take the shot I wanted.  I tried full manual mode, auto without flash, iso at 6400 and lots and lots of other settings but the camera just would not attempt a shot at all, nada, neyt.  Several days earlier in a mountain top chapel in Moustiers (central Provence), in light so dim I could hardly see 8 feet in front of me and my eyes took minutes to adjust, the 60D took amazing photos on high iso and wide aperture settings.  Playing back the chapel photos revealed detail barely discernible to my eyes in the darkness, yet the brightly moonlit clearly visible to my eyes huge rock escarpment was for reasons unknown to me not something the 60D was willing to spend SD card storage space on, and yes there was plenty of room on the card, lots of battery power..yada...yada.  Extremely frustrating.  I hope there is an explanation that cites operator error.  More experience photographers have complained that the 60D does a poor job of autofocusing in low light conditions and perhaps this caused the camera to refuse to take the shot.Love many things about the 60D.  It is a much better camera than my photography skills warrant and many of my 1300 photos from this trip (writing review from hotel in La Ciotat, France) are nice due to it's capabilities not mine, but why the camera should second guess even a novice and refuse the shot is baffling.

Reviews.Title: Great DSLR camera!
Reviews.Author: chewie
Reviews.Content: I debated for a while before buying a DSLR-- I wish I did'nt. Compared to a point and shoot- Its night and day. Although the 60d is a step down from the XXd series. Build wise and FPS- I think its a great camera for someone to jump onto the DSLR world.  Better than the Rebel series and not as fancy as a 7DI think it has been priced lower than the 50d when it was introduced.The one thing that I dont like about the 60d is that the autofocus while taking a picture using "Live View" is slow and sketchy for anything thats moving.Other than that Its GREEEEEAT!

Reviews.Title: Great looking Photos!
Reviews.Author: TerraDan
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera just to capture great detail when taking pics of my portrait art to post on my website.  My expectations have been exceeded and I am so happy I chose this camera over all the others I researched.  The HD-video on this camera is a really nice feature as well.  After I purchased it I found out that I had to have a class 6 or higher sd card in order for the video feature to work.  So, I bought a class 10 sd card and now the video feature runs flawlessly.  I've the camera now for about a month and I am still learning new things about it.  Check out some pics I've taken with it that I've posted on my website.  [...]

Reviews.Title: Great camera by Canon
Reviews.Author: Vamsi
Reviews.Content: As earlier Canon did not disappoint me. I owned a Powershot for a little more than 5 years and decided to move to a DSLR as I felt the controls provided by Powershot were too less for the kind of photos that I wanted to capture. Also, I was not ready to take the big DSLR bull by horn and was looking for an intermediate yet powerful DSLR and am now glad that I chose EOS 60D. Canon's swivel LCD, excellent controls, sturdy build and a great kit lens, make this camera my best one so far.A tip - Along with this kit lens, buy a prime lens like Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 II Camera Lens (right now its 100$ on Amazon and is a great value for the price)and you wouldn't need any other lens for years to come (unless you are a professional or if you really want to shoot a whale pod from the top of Space Needle).

Reviews.Title: High expectations, and it delivered!
Reviews.Author: SuperDave
Reviews.Content: I was in dire need of an upgrade and was seriously looking at the 7D.  Realizing that the 7D is rumored for a "refresh" in early 2012, I didn't want to spend the extra money versus the 60D.  Ultimately, I opted for the 60D and I have to say, I don't feel like I'm missing anything from the 7D!  This is a fantastic camera and I don't see how anyone would be disappointed with it! And props to Amazon for their speedy delivery!

Reviews.Title: Best dslr for the money!
Reviews.Author: Jarhead
Reviews.Content: Having used cameras since 1961 (manual rangefinder Yashica) four different slr's, and numerous digital cameras, ending up with a Fuji HS-10, the Canon 60D is the very top.  I will miss the 30X zoom of the HS-10, but the ability to get usable images at ISO 3200 out weighs that.  My 60D came with the 18-135 IS, and I will soon be adding the 55-250 IS which will give me a 14X range.  The Canon 60D with the efs 18-135is lens surely rates my 5 stars - plus Amazon's customer service is first rate.

Reviews.Title: cano 60 D
Reviews.Author: F. Terkoski
Reviews.Content: Camera so far has been an outstanding purchase.  Price at $1199 was below everyone else.  Camera came on time and in great shape.  Experimented at an Airshow on the first weekend and folks were amazed at the zoom quality of the 18 - 135mm lens, excellent clarity and fantastic fast speed shooting.  Color indoors with flash so far is exceptional.  Can't wait to take it to Grand Canyon in 2 weeks for a hefty tryout.Having to hold button to unlock and rotate mode wheel is only minor complaint so far.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic buy
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This is the purchase from Amazon that makes me proud. This camera is a great buy for beginners as well as professional/semi-professionals. If you've never tried a dSLR and want to try one, Canon EOS 60D is a great place to start. Ideally, for better photos, you should get a good quality tripod and a good remote control. But the image stabilization in the lens and the body both give a great picture if you hold your camera reasonably steady. A good add-on would be a nice polarizer or some filter. Try the manual mode in this product and you'll get to see the array of things you can do with raw images.1. Very good documentation2. Very good body construction3. Excellent lens - I wish the aperture were more, but then it would cost far more.4. Great stabilization5. 1/8000th of a second shutter speeds.

Reviews.Title: Love it so far
Reviews.Author: A. Kelling
Reviews.Content: Great camera. Really great to switch between photos and movies - instantly! Very convenient. High quality. Lots of fun in the couple weeks of having it.

Reviews.Title: Wow!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: The last SLR I owned was a Canon Rebel 2000 35mm. I liked that camera, but until digital came along, I could never really understand how to set my camera the way I wanted to. That is, not without wasting rolls and rolls of film. Something I never could justify doing. Then came the digital age of photography and I embraced it with a passion. But until recently I could never afford another SLR. Along comes the Canon 60D and a surgery that required three weeks of recovery (a blessing in disguise). Sitting in my recliner with my Canon 60D in hand, I watched every youtube video and every article I could find on the internet about photography and the 60D itself (literally hundreds of hours). It was a free college course in photography from my easy chair. And in the process I got to know my new camera inside and out. Let me tell you, I was not disappointed. It has everything an aspiring amateur is looking for in a camera (other places will give better details than me). I must say that every time I think that my camera might be lacking in one area or another, I have been proved wrong. I do recommend that if you are buying this camera, I would get a kit lens with it. I opted to get just the body, because I still had the lenses from my Rebel Camera, but the kit lenses are made for the new digitals and for a couple hundred dollars more you get a good performing lens.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera, some accessories should be standard...
Reviews.Author: M. WU "mwu"
Reviews.Content: Overall, it is a great camera.Canon, please listen, lens hood should be a "come with" standard accessory, since the 18-135mm lens is already come with it, why not the lens hood?  Remote control should be a "come with" standard accessory as well, rather I have to buy it separately.Great camera for both entry-level or semi-pro users, lots of controls, I love those easy-access controls on top and on LCD screen.  LCD screen can be flipped out or covered, a very nice feature.However, it is a little bit heavy to hang around on your neck for hours... Be warned...

Reviews.Title: Love it
Reviews.Author: Kindle Customer "vaz"
Reviews.Content: I'm going to keep my review short. I love this Camera. I replaced a t2i with the 60D and the new options were worth it. The articulating screen has come in handy many times and I certainly hope this is the direction cannon will choose with all future DSLR's. I've produced a lot of beautiful imagery with the 60D. I chose it over the 7D because of price obviously, but I feel the 7D is meant for photographers with higher demands than me, especially those who need every ounce of speed for fast action, or can just plain afford it. For what I use the 60D for it is well suited (portraits of people, some wildlife, anything interesting I see). I think the 60D is right where it needs to be for kind of middle range photographers with medium demands of speed.

Reviews.Title: It's now up to your photo eye that makes the difference
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I've been a lifelong Canon consumer and while not a pro photographer , I have enough experience after owning this camera for 6 months to know that there is enough built in capability with the 60d to put the burden of good photos squarely on the user. Sure, there are some deficiencies with the equipment to require workarounds, but it's superb enough to make the photographers creative abilities the limiting factor, not the camera. That's all you need you need to know before buying. For a reasonable price, you get enough cam and lens to do it all and more if you add a canon flash, and perhaps a specialty lens if you have a particular need.  Other than that it's a great package and I love to shoot with it. If you are used to the canon user interface, it's very intuitive and in conjunction with some decent post processing software ( aperture for me), I can pretty much do it all. I highly recommend this package for photographers who love to shoot but don't do it for a living. I travel extensively, and love to have this as my main camera, and paired with a canon s95 pocket cam, I'm always ready to capture the world visually. Hope this helps others like me that love to bring the world home with them.  I also can't praise the s95 enough as a pocket cam, so look at that too.

Reviews.Title: 60D is a star
Reviews.Author: Lucky44
Reviews.Content: This camera, to me, is the absolute best in class when considering performance, features and price.  The only thing it is missing is true AF capability when shooting video.

Reviews.Title: My first DSLR, I watched and waited until now, and I'm glad.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Proud Liberal = fighter for ...
Reviews.Content: This camera is not just a great value at the price, but a genuine pleasure to use. It's true that as my first DSLR, I can't compare it to owning anything else, but I have used others, and this definitely compares well.Solidly built. I have bumped this camera around all over New Mexico for 6 months, with no problems. I got the 18-135mm kit lens, and it is simply superb. I do not think I would have been happy with the 18-55mm kit. This rig is a handful, but I don't mind lugging it around. I use a hand grip strap and much of the time when in a target-rich environment, I just leave it strapped onto my hand fairly comfortably, at the ready to swing it u to my eye and shoot. I recently added a Canon EFS 55-250mm lens, and it is a bit lighter, due to all-plastic barrel and mount. I love everything about this new lens, too. The design and build quality of the Canon high-end consumer line is outstanding in its class.As far as operation, once you learn the uses of the various modes and functions, there are no surprises. As an aerospace computer engineer who works with the controls and displays on military planes, this camera works the way I had expected in every respect, which is a very positive thing to say in my case. The Live View mode (where you use the LCD screen as a viewfinder) is fairly worthless, because it doesn't autofocus well in that mode. If you're shooting over heads in a crowd, you could go to Live View (one button press toggles it ON/OFF), use the articulated screen to line it up, switch it off and shoot. I have always preferred the conventional viewfinder anyway, so it doesn't bother me.  Also, I am still learning how to best keep it focused when using the video mode, but the videos are excellent. Before I start doing that a lot, I need to get an external microphone (about $60 for an acceptable one) that mounts on the hot-shoe.I got a couple of extra batteries (not much $), but the power use is so efficient and the capacity so good that I only keep the extras with me so that I'll have a fresh one on hand whenever the one in the camera happens to run low (after many hundreds of shots), and I might have expended two full charges in a long day of shooting once or twice.I work with an animal rescue group, so it's important to be able to repeatedly fire with no delay between shots or at power-on and come away with decent shots reliably. This camera does the job well.

Reviews.Title: Very nice DSLR, Camera
Reviews.Author: r_kwon
Reviews.Content: The Canon 60d is definitely a great buy. I was extremely impressed with the pictures and video it produced. However, the 18-135mm lens is honestly just average, which is expected for a kit lens. The quality isn't terrible, but if you're thinking about getting serious in the DSLR world, I'd suggest getting a better lens. I would still advise you to get the 18-135mm kit because the lens itself is around $400.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: JMC
Reviews.Content: I'll start off by listing out my only complains about this camera:- It's not made out of magnesium alloy like it's older brothers.- It doesn't have micro-adjustment.- The t3i has optical 3-10x zoom, this doesn't.Other than that, I really find no problem with this camera. I mean it fits right in between the t3i and the 7D, in terms of size, price, built quality, and performance.My original reason to buy this for filming and I picked this one over the 7D, despite the built quality difference, because it had manual audio level adjustments. So for those who mainly want it for filming and not much of photography, just go for the t3i, it's cheaper and it offers more than this.Now, even though the t3i is better in terms of video and my original purpose for it was filming, I've seen myself use it a lot more in photography so those extra fps come in handy when needed. Another thing about that I like over the t3i, is that this one is actually bigger and adding on the battery grip, it feels very solid and it just feels right in my hand.Regardless, this camera is really good and you won't regret buying it.

Reviews.Title: Canon EOS 60 D
Reviews.Author: Blogman45
Reviews.Content: I have been in the pro still/video business creating documentaries, self-help, corporate and marketing industry for years and found that this mid-priced camera does about everything I need for still and video shots for my business. In some cases it outperforms some of my older, equipment costing 2 to 3 times as much.I just received it so I am still testing it out but so far, it does everything the manufacturer says it will while producing some amazing stills and videos. For me, this is a keeper in my arsenal of picture/video taking equipment for my business.The lens provided with this purchase is OK but, if you want some even better results, I recommend upgrading to a more professional Canon lens.Canon EOS 60D 18 MP CMOS Digital SLR Camera with 3.0-Inch LCD and 18-135mm f/3.5-5.6 IS UD Standard Zoom Lens

Reviews.Title: Expect the best and get get it.
Reviews.Author: Michael Denardo
Reviews.Content: Having been a Canon user for many years I knew which camera was next from Amazon.com. This is my fourth Canon that began with the Rebel series. I have moved up to better quality and better features each and every time; this newest Canon is no exception. Don't miss out. Everyone will tell you, "Gee, your camera takes good pictures."

Reviews.Title: Love Love it!
Reviews.Author: S. Ababio "Azonto"
Reviews.Content: I am in love with this camera, I just upgraded from a rebel t1i which could not meet my demands since I am now learning more and moving up.But this camera is great, fast, great quality.This whole thing of metallic body vs. plastic is not the way I will choose my camera.Even though the its plastic, it feels good to hold.The built-in flash is not too hash on pictures compare to the other camera, although I use the 430ex flash.The ergonomic design is also good compare to t1i.My advise is even you are new to dslr I say start with this model because if you start with a low end once you become good you will need a higher camera.With the flip lcd I have been able to take some good angle pics in live view.Hmm...what else....just love it!

Reviews.Title: review from a beginner
Reviews.Author: erhan
Reviews.Content: I believe I will learn to love my (and my wife's) camera, as I learn how to use it :)It seems possible to create amazing photos with one click, though.One thing I noticed, I need a zoom and perhaps one macro lens to shoot nature, plants and animals...Well another... its heavy to use with one hand :)

Reviews.Title: Good for middle level photographer
Reviews.Author: poopup
Reviews.Content: I really like this. This is my second camera since my first D30 10 years ago.It really worth for my money. I love the swap screen. It's so cool

Reviews.Title: Best camera I ever had
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I owned several SLR's (film+digital) before; this is by far the best camera I ever had.The ability to auto-ISO to 6400ASA created incredible photo's at the most challenging lighting conditions

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Dan
Reviews.Content: Seriously a great camera. Video modes are perfect and pictures look great. There is some noise when viewed at 100% though, and it gets worse as you get up in ISO but it's not much worse than the Nikon D7000. Canon's decision to use the same sensor as in the T2i and 7d, not to improve the focusing from the aging 50D, and failure to offer many appealing new features for the pro photographer led many to criticize the camera. Though, even with these shortcomings, the Canon 60D remains a solid DSLR for many aspiring pro photographers while integrating a slew of dream features to aspiring videographers at an aggressive price point. Full review of the camera here: [...]

Reviews.Title: Very good DSLR
Reviews.Author: Lewis H DeVore, Jr
Reviews.Content: I have only used point and shoot dscs.  My last SLR was a film based model - the Canon EOS-A2.  This camera is very nice so far.  I especially like the picture styles, and the ability to customize the settings.  The included software is very capable for processing raw files.  I was pleasantly surprised with the video quality.  The 1080p videos are stunning!  I do wish that autofocus capability was available for videos though.  All in all this is a solid camera.  I purchased a Tamron 18-270 zoom which works very nicely with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Perfect upgrade from my t2i.
Reviews.Author: George Rodriguez "George"
Reviews.Content: First let me say I am still new to photography. I've been shooting with dslr's for a little over a year and love it. I started with a t2i a couple of months after it's release. That camera was good to me but I grew out of it in about 2 months. Once I started shooting weekly I felt as the t2i wasn't durable enough due to it's weak platic feel. It also couldn't do things I needed it to do without going into the menus to make changes along with other things. I decided to look for upgrades in the canon family and was deciding between the 6oD and the 7D. A buddy I know stopped by my office and was showing off his 7D which I thought was nice but a little on the heavy side. It also has a higher price tag then I was looking to spend. I started looking at videos on you tube and found a video called "60D training video" it's from canon. Once I seen this video I immediately went out and purchased one. It has so many cool features for video and photo. The build is much better, the look with the swivel LCD , the grip fits my hand perfectly! When it comes to quality of the photos and video the t2i/60D/7D are not much different(also depends on your lens), Though I think my 60D performed better in low light for video. My 60D also has a faster burst which is great for when I am at the zoo with my kids or watching my nephew's baseball game catching all the action! If you decide to purchase this camera you will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera!
Reviews.Author: EGsimi
Reviews.Content: This is an outstanding camera!  This is my first DSLR however I have used for much of my life old film SLR cameras since I can remember.  So Digital is a little new for me outside of the simple point and click cameras.I have a Canon 50D at work and was planning on buying one of those for myself but the 60D was available for the same price so I figured I would go for it.  I am glad I did.  I have had the 60D for a little over a week and have already shot nearly 500 pictures with it and figure to go over a thousand this weekend.  This morning I had to do some work with my companies 50D and suddenly realized how much of an improvement the 60D really is.  Both are excellent models however the layout and control functions are much more intuitive with the 60D and the ergonomics are improved.The flip out swivel screen was one reason I was NOT going to buy the 60D.  I figured it was just one more thing to break and seemed kind of like a gimmick to me.  However after using the camera for a period of time and then going back to the 50D I realized why this was not the case.  From simply being able to fold the screen away safely into the camera so as to avoid scratches or nose prints when shooting to being able to angle the screen for better viewing I have found it to be very useful, well constructed and a better feature than the fixed screen on the back of the 50D (or other similar style cameras).one feature I am very excited about is the Bulb feature.  I honestly do not know if the 50D has this feature however it is clearly marked and accessible on the 60D.  this allows you to set up the camera and hold the shutter open for as long as you like by simply pressing the shutter button or using one of the remote triggering options (of course sold separately). This is great for night time sky shots and will be getting a lot of use.It is a Canon so you know that there is quality there and support as well as a full feature line up of lenses.  I have owned Canon point and shoot digital cameras in the past and many of the features and controls are very similar.  Canon enthusiasts should be able to pick it up and start shooting within minutes of familiarizing themselves with the camera.  However even those not familiar with canon products will find the basic functions of this camera easy to pick up and understand quickly.If you are interested in upgrading from the Rebel line of cameras and are looking to make the next step up from Amateur DSLR cameras of any make to a more robust system or if you are one of the remaining old film junkies who are looking to get a well appointed DSLR this camera should be on your short list for consideration.

Reviews.Title: Canon 60d review
Reviews.Author: dave b
Reviews.Content: Pros:Excellent battery life.Excellent images.Flexibility.Tilty swiveley LCD screen.5.3 fps burst speed.Full HD video.Cons:I hate the on/off switch.Door to battery hard to open.It's kinda heavy.The left wheel should go all the way around.I've used the Canon 60d about 1 month now and I love it. Don't get too caught up in the cons.  They're very minor. This camera rocks! I looked at several other camers in this price range and none had the features of the Canon 60d.  My previous Sony non-DSLR had a moving LCD and I didn't think I could live without one.  The zoom on the 18-135 is nice and sharp.  The controls are well placed. The HD video is excellent although I haven't used it much yet.The Canon 60d makes an excellent first DSLR.  I would buy it all over again.

Reviews.Title: Little watered down, and canon needs to up their game with sensor design
Reviews.Author: K. Dardashti "Electronics fan"
Reviews.Content: I have owned many camera bodies, including xti, t2i, 40d, 60d, 7d, 5d and 5dII.  I purchased this as a backup for to my 5d2, and for shooting long and some birds.  I initially bought a t2i, but found the ergonomics, and buffer poor.  I purchased 60D as it shares the same battery as my 5d2, and has much better ergonomics.What I love:  The external flash control, on board flash, general build and ergonomics.What I dislike, in Order:1.Sensor efficiency.  Nikon has canon beat here.  the dynamic range on d7000 is a fair bit superior, esp important if you are doing landscape.  Canon needs to improve their sensor production in the next line.2. Lack of focus microadjustment.  Why?  it does not cost much to include, and is a very very useful feature.things that I wish were included but not a deal breaker:  extra custom settings, a non locking mode dial.

Reviews.Title: 20D - 40D - 60D? not really
Reviews.Author: Steven G.
Reviews.Content: For the past 13 years I have been a consistent Canon EOS xxD buyer. I am now, a not-so-proud owner of the latest Canon 60D for the past three weeks.I switched over from the film to the digital world with a Canon 20D. I bought an additional 40D mainly because of the electronic chip cleaning feature, and now purchased the Canon 60D because of its HD capability and the 20D is starting to show its age.Other people before me have reviewed the specific details and differences between the other Canon models, so I will not go there, but I will explain a few of my disappointments with the new 60D.1) The 60D does not have the magnesium frame, so the picture taking capacity rating goes down from 150,000 pictures to 100,000. Yes, this is an issue for me, but to be honest, not as much as I thought it would be. The camera does feel lighter, but that makes it actually a bit easier to handle and frankly, even with my 20D, I took ~26,000 pictures and had to have it repaired recently because the mirror switch gave out.2) From 6.3 fps to 5.3 fps. I often shoot wildlife action pictures, and that is 1 frame less which can make a difference between a good or a bad picture.3) The setting for taking HD footage is a major pain to get to. The user has to completely dial to the end of the different settings (I usually shoot M), and on top of that, you have to push a button in the middle of the dial to allow switching between different shooting modes. And yes, you cannot dial in 360 degree mode, so must go all the way back to the M mode.4) The remote release (TC-80N3) does not work anymore with this model. Likely because it is not a direct upgrade from a 40D/50D but rather an `upgraded' Rebel. In addition, Canon currently does not sell a bracket/timer remote control. Pearstone's RC-C1 seems to work though, but is additional equipment and additional cost.5) The autofocus system is the same as that of the 40D/50D, which is a disappointment after waiting for such a long time.6) The joystick dial is now replaced with an 8-directional dial, which is much more time consuming to use.Overall, I am disappointed with this move from Canon. The 7D is supposed to be the successor to the 50D, but then why is it $600 more expensive? Even if this logic holds true, why come out with a camera that has on purpose features to slow down normal operations (like the push button to switch between shooting modes, or the time it takes to switch between M and video).Yes, the video is great, yes, the megapixels are a nice upgrade from my 40D, but we are seriously considering returning this camera and looking at the Nikon D7000. The 7D without lens is almost the same price as the D7000 with lens and the specs seem much better for the D7000 then the 60D. I have been a loyal Canon buyer, but the 30% price hike for me to get a similar product line I already had opens up the door for me to look at another model.

Reviews.Title: upgraded from t2i
Reviews.Author: punworld "hd_pun"
Reviews.Content: i just upgrade from t2i.its stronger build than t2i.i love the screen ,i can now take picture with different angle.i did try d7000 which i returned,it was good camera but canon screen and 18 megapixel made me choose 60d.

Reviews.Title: What a bargain, what a deal...
Reviews.Author: Obasina aka "TheOne"
Reviews.Content: There are more "Pros" than "Cons" here folks, be you a Pro, Am, or Wannabe...Cons1. No PC Sync (definite step down for me; I like to have the option if I happen to run out of batteries for the PW's...if you've been using the EOS Rebel series, this is a "no biggy")2. I don't like the fact that I you can't delete multiple items at the same time without formatting the card3. The battery life seems a little less that the BP511's from my 30 & 40d's4. Personally not very crazy about the "vid" option being all the way on the opposite side of the LOCKING selection dial5. Still not made for left-handers...I know, I know, I know...Again, most of my "Cons" are personal, quirky things that I probably wouldn't be complaining about had I had the money to invest in the 7D or 5Dii, which I will in time (with exception of the "left-handed" issue)...I didn't take the time out to gripe about the plastic body or the size of the cam or it's slightly-slower-than-8fps performance; I bout an OEM battery grip and I'm being more patient to get the shot that most important. These were things I knew going into the purchase and really aren't enough to hinder me from getting another cam if I ever really needed to.Pros1) cam and vid capabilities2) 6400+ ISO3) noticeable improvements in white balance compensation4) great horizon finder5) the RC-6 remote actually works6) exquisite CANON craftsmanship (processors, res, articulating monitor, functionality, lots of very kool "tricks" it can do if you like "tricks"...I really could go on...)7) really easy to use8) for all of you who simply refuse to read the Owner's Manual, there are some really kool "cheat sheets" for you (lol)9) priceNo, It's not a 7D or a 5Dii and truly not a 1DS/V, BUT, if you're down to only 1 cam and it happens to get stolen and you didn't have it insured, THIS IS A VERY GREAT OPTION to get you back in the saddle! FYI: You're going to need to make a small investment in SDHC or SDXC cards if you've used CF's in the past. The manual tells you Class 6 or better, but if you're going to be doing any real level of vid production, don't even waste the time with anything less than a Class 10 card (20mb's or faster)Oh yeah, it arrived on time and well packaged. Thank you to the seller for excellent work to get it here in a due and timely manner.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Aperture Academy
Reviews.Content: As a photography educator, I work with just about every brand and model of camera you can think of. I've been impressed with the Canon 60D, especially the combination of live view and the flip out screen. It's such a great way to teach composition.

Reviews.Title: So far, so good
Reviews.Author: RobMac
Reviews.Content: Love the camera so far.  Great price, excellent quality.My ONLY complaint is that the camera does not auto-focus when you are taking HD video.  So when I took test video of my dogs, I had to continuously manually focus the camera as the dogs moved closer to me.  It's a pain, but the HD video picture is superb.

Reviews.Title: Canon 60D
Reviews.Author: Robert J. Collins
Reviews.Content: Having owned every Canon Digital SLR since the original Digital Rebel, the 60D finally offers the flip out and rotatable screen... which I had in my old Olympus Digital with the fixed lense.That mostly sums up why I bought the camera... I sold my 50D on Amazon soon thereafter.The 60D is an addition to my Canon 7D, so I have a walkaround Tamron 18-270 on the 60D and my Canon 100-400 on the 7D. I'm ready for just about anything.

Reviews.Title: canon is great!
Reviews.Author: Scotty S. "ss_imaging"
Reviews.Content: First dslr I purchased, strong build quality, no flaws! Can't wait till I can get a full frame canon 1dx! Canon beats Nikon!

Reviews.Title: Professional results in the hands of a perpetual amateur
Reviews.Author: David Bailey "Embedded Wizard"
Reviews.Content: I'm not inexperience with photography, but my experience has lately been limited to compact digital cameras without attachments. The most you have to deal with, is taking the camera out of a zippered case and turning it on. Back in the day, I carried a Minolta 35mm SLR. In those days, I had three lenses, filters, a tripod, batteries and rolls of film (under-, over-, and properly-exposed). There WERE no second chances...either you exposed it right or you wasted it. Today's prosumer digital SLRs are a different story. There are second chances galore. If you can't get a good picture, it's because you missed the moment by not being ready for it. Although this camera is heavier than any camera I have carried, it more than makes up for it in the quality department. When I carry it, I constantly look for challenges. A closeup here, a landscape there, a group photo here, a portrait there. It masters them all. The automatic modes alone are comprehensive enough to allow the photographer to become lazy about lens stops, shutter speeds and ISO settings. Everything magically comes out sharp and clear, with or without flash. And the lens that came with the camera! Image-stabilized, autofocus, adjustable from a nice wide group-friendly 28mm to a very satisfying telephoto of 135 mm and everything in between. What's not to like? I can't see muself outgrowing this camera. You could say I like it, but you'd be wrong. I love it!

Reviews.Title: Perfect for Low-Budget Film-Makers!
Reviews.Author: River
Reviews.Content: I got this camera because I am a low-budget film-maker, and this camera seemed to fit the bill. It met all of my expectations. Originally, I was looking for a better camera, but realized that this one was far better quality than I really needed. The most important part of film-making is the skill of the crew, not the quality of the equipment.

Reviews.Title: Classical Canon DSLR
Reviews.Author: michael
Reviews.Content: For me as a student, to buy a SLR at a reasonable price but don't want to go a rebel line which seems quite cheap, plastic or whatever, 60d is a pretty good choice. Compared with 70d which is a newer model at almost twice the price, their image quality is almost the same, and their body looks identical. You save several hundred dollars to get a good lens, that's the truth! Try to avoid holding a cheap lens with somewhat 3.5-5.6 or 4.0-5.6. For me, I just hold my 50mm 1.4 Prime! Sometimes we do need other focal length, just borrow or rent one. For most of the time, your legs can be your zoom ring!

Reviews.Title: No Brainer. This is the way to go. Dont even waste time reading anymore reviews. You can read mine but it's not necessary.
Reviews.Author: N. Hedgeman
Reviews.Content: If you are thinking about getting an EOS... Don't this is better. Solid, professional. Amazing pictures and video. Will be buying at least two more. For me and what I shoot, which are live band performances, low light, pictures and video? Out door events, promotions for local businesses... it does everything I need it to do exceptionally well.Like with all cameras... Get some good glass. Have a post production work flow. Have a reliable rig. But this camera will not be the weak link in your work chain.Shoots HD 1080p 30/24 fps. Seriously... what else do you need? Has a mic input. HDMI out for a external LCD. USB for remote shooting. Hot shoe. Really, only thing going to replace mine is a 5D.If you aren't gonna buy a full frame, and you aren't shooting sports or humming birds. This is the best way to go. Price being a factor. You can buy other cameras that will have different features, but I haven't found one that justified being anymore expensive than this one. And even the ones that are cheaper, are missing features that I find necessary for any serious photographer or videographer.

Reviews.Title: very impressed - after two weeks
Reviews.Author: daleg
Reviews.Content: Having suffered the theft of my extensive nikon system many years ago, I limped through the past ten or so years with a canon G2 - which wasn't that bad, given its limitations. Finally, it was time to plunge back into the pool. About 2 weeks ago a new 60D w/18-200mm kit arrived. Gulp, which immediately gave me a big smile and an even bigger learning curve to face - which I'll be busy climbing for quite a while.  Meanwhile, the more I've learned, the more I've been impressed.  To date, no regrets. One observation: Canon needs a 2 for 1 sale on "L" lenses.  Really.

Reviews.Title: Loved it!
Reviews.Author: Praveen Basnet
Reviews.Content: Great camera if you're stepping up from entry level Dslr. Great Feature works perfect. I absolutely love it. Must buy!!

Reviews.Title: You don't need to learn photography
Reviews.Author: Pavel
Reviews.Content: As The title said, you don't need to learn photography, use the built in configs ( portrait, landscape, close up etc) and you are going to get a professional photo. Only thing you need to know, when to choose what. Moreover, if you know little bit about shutter speed and aperture control, you can take those nice picture with the same quality as you have seen in your desktop wallpaper and I am not joking.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Mark Fischer
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera to both take photos and Video.  It does both really well.  It is bit heavy especially with a big lens and extra battery pack, but it is well worth the work out.  Pictures and video have been of a superb quality.

Reviews.Title: Loved it to the core
Reviews.Author: Anusha Aluri
Reviews.Content: This camera takes awesome pictures. I took pictures on my sister's wedding and they came out so well. Worth buying!

Reviews.Title: The best DSLR ever! Perfect for starting out in photography!
Reviews.Author: Navam H.
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! I was a novice to photography when I bought this, but here I am a couple of months later, getting ready to do my first few events.A pricey choice as an entry-level camera but its money very well invested. Friends who have used it vs. similar ranged Nikon's like the D7000 or the D5100 have called it better than their own cameras.

Reviews.Title: Excelente Quality
Reviews.Author: Daniel Perez Miranda
Reviews.Content: Excelent image quality, fast, quiet, accurate, very good in low light and nice lcd display. A big step up from my previous Canon XTi.

Reviews.Title: Canon 60D - thumbs up
Reviews.Author: Janusz Raszewski
Reviews.Content: it is a very good camera. It took some punishment in a desert and still works fine. Good range of features for beginners and seasoned users alike.

Reviews.Title: Better colours than my 5d mk2 and very good screen
Reviews.Author: Dylan_ Sri Lanka
Reviews.Content: A good secondary camera to have reliable and gets the job done. battery life is excellent with a battery grip you will never run out of batter ever again

Reviews.Title: Love Canon
Reviews.Author: Peter M H
Reviews.Content: I guess I'm a Canon fan. My first camera was an AE-1 mostly shooting slides, then a PowerShot A620 which brought me into the digital age. I intended on not getting a DSLR, but even though the PowerShot serves me well, I needed more. I chose the 60D because of it's larger feel in hand, flip out LCD screen, HD video, and of course all the other abilities of a DSLR. This camera is awesome!

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Frank W. Guy
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.....it shoots amazing video and so inexpensive......well worth the money!  I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a slr camera.

Reviews.Title: Best buy of recent times
Reviews.Author: Gabriel
Reviews.Content: Canon EOS 60D 18 MP CMOS Digital SLR Camera with 3.0-Inch LCD and 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS UD Standard Zoom Lenseach of the accessory package that contained by accessory by accessory, know the real size.Excellent product, with its 18 megapixel photographs are all handsome, works great on full HD video, the macro lens 18mm to 55mm very good for what I needed.so far in these 15 days has been a very good choice for purchase.Thanks for the seller that his service was very good.Atentamente,GabrielNote: The lens is pictured s not the same, the lens of the camera that acquired is 18-55mm.thanks

Reviews.Title: Chose this over a 7D, and im very happy with my decision
Reviews.Author: AMZ
Reviews.Content: Initially i had planned to buy a Canon 7D, but upon further research and a sad realization of my actual budget, i decided to go with the 60D and i havent regret it! this camera is light, feels solid, and is just an overall good camera. the rotating screen is very nice for taking video at low angles and for tilting down so i can see the screen while the camera is on my 6 foot tall tripod and taking high angle shots.

Reviews.Title: Perfect !!!!
Reviews.Author: Bernardo Sales
Reviews.Content: Excelent camera. You can take beautiful photos with this camera. It's a little expensive but you won't be disappointed. Buy !!!

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera!
Reviews.Author: Jonathan B. Quick
Reviews.Content: The camera was exactly what I hoped it would be. I used it in a trip to Europe and it took amazing pictures.

Reviews.Title: Very nice camera would recommend
Reviews.Author: Elroz
Reviews.Content: We had this camera for over 10 years and then it stopped auto focusing. I had all the good lenses for it so just bought the new "body"

Reviews.Title: Canon  60D
Reviews.Author: Garnett Wallace "wallycat44"
Reviews.Content: I have been a Canon user since my first camera, the Canon Ftb-QL, and have used many models since then. My most recent camera was a 20D which I finally wore out! I decided on the 60D because of good reviews on Amazon and other sites. I also wanted a camera with video capabilities for photographing my grandchildren. And, I love the fact that most Canon DSLR bodies will connect to nearly all their lenses. When friends and former students ask me for camera recommendations, I push them toward Canon - you cannot go wrong with them!

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: Jeff Brannon
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera for a photography class and also to shoot some student films. The camera is awesome and works great for both film and photography.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Camera
Reviews.Author: Kristi Bernstein
Reviews.Content: This is my first camera purchase since the 1st generation Rebel DSLRs came out. It was worth the wait and worth every penny!! Amazing camera. No complaints here!! Canon lover forever!!FYI, this camera did take almost 2 months to arrive from Amazon. Don't be in a huge hurry to get it at your door!

Reviews.Title: Solid Camera for a Solid Price
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I am a semi-professional photographer that wanted to start producing my photos on canvas and poster paper for sale.  I had been looking at purchasing the Canon 60D or the Canon 7D.  The main difference I found between these two cameras was weight.  The 60D is a lot lighter then its 7D brother.  By no means is it cheaply constructed, it just has a feather light frame to it.  Once I had a lens attached to the body I found that the balance was great for shooting and that being lighter actually made carrying the camera on walking journeys a lot better then my older more heavy camera.  Also, price was obviously a very impressive argument for the purchase of the 60D over the 7D.  So I chose to go with this model.After weeding through many fake websites trying to sell me cheap knock offs and packages of accessories I didn't want, I decided to purchase this camera through Amazon.  It was the best choice I could have made.  Not only did I get exactly the item that I wanted, but with the Amazon Prime membership and 3$ for shipping I was able to get my camera THE NEXT DAY!  I was out shooting with my new camera in 2 days!

Reviews.Title: Perfect
Reviews.Author: RenatoAchkar
Reviews.Content: No words to say about this camera. My first DSLR and great photos!!!After using every day during this weekend I recommend this camera, easy to use for beginers and you have a choice to increase photo skills with the same camera.About the  $$$ 18-200 is the best!

Reviews.Title: Amazing
Reviews.Author: Caro Smart "Caro S"
Reviews.Content: I LOVE this camera!!! The only negative thing I can say about it is that it's on the heavy side.Taking that aside, this is the BEST camera ever!!!!

Reviews.Title: cool camera
Reviews.Author: Ani
Reviews.Content: well as a beginner in photo shooting i was recommended to buy canon 60D and just wanted to say that this camera is so cute and nice that even with the low experience in photo shooting the pictures become incredible so recommend all the beginners who would like to have incredible moments shot.

Reviews.Title: Canon EOS 60D Camera
Reviews.Author: DustyShoe
Reviews.Content: After a lengthy review of DSLR cameras by Canon, I decided upon the 60D.  It has a big 3" display with good quality imagery. It is easy to use, versatile, and includes video ability. It is rated number one by consumer report and does an excellent job in performance.  I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a new DSLR camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon 60D
Reviews.Author: dn
Reviews.Content: Fantastic camera and worth the extra $180 over the T3i.  The lesser priced models feel cheap compared to the 60D and 7D. I like that you can shoot both RAW and Jpeg at the same time without having to press a temp function like on the 7D.It arrived quickly even though it was on back order.  It would be nice if Canon would offer better lenses with their kits for this camera.

Reviews.Title: powerful, fun and versatile Canon 60D
Reviews.Author: ThomasC "Thomas C."
Reviews.Content: While I am new to DSLRs I am not new to photography. There is a learning curve with this camera. It has many functions that allow pictures to be taken in many different settings and allow the photographer to really create something special. While you could just put it on auto, it really defeats the purpose of all the power that manual allows. Take the time and learn how to use it. You will be rewarded. Otherwise there are plenty of good point-and-shoots out there.

Reviews.Title: Best camera I have ever owned
Reviews.Author: Jim Smith "Jim Smith"
Reviews.Content: I tried the canon 60D and nikon D7000 and decided to go with the 60D.60D was less expensive than the D7000.60D raw editing software came with camera and was free yet very powerful.D7000 did not come with raw editing software and costs an additional $180 for capture NX2 :-(Video on the 60D is more cinematic with more manual control.60D will film at 60 fps and D7000 max frame rate is 30 fps. 60 fps great for slow motion and analyzing my golf swing.60D is lighter and easier to carry around.60D has a much bigger buffer when taking many continuous shots.  The D7000 buffer would fill up after about 3 seconds of taking raw photos.

Reviews.Title: Canon EOS 60D
Reviews.Author: Matt
Reviews.Content: Canon EOS 60D 18 MP CMOS Digital SLR Camera with 3.0-Inch LCD (Body Only)this is a great startup camera for any amateur that wants more advanced features. You can take still photos and live video in HD. I have bought this camera about a year ago I have upgraded from canon 50d it is definitely better than my previous canon 50d . This camera has more features. 18 megapixel. Definitely recommended camera. [...]

Reviews.Title: Great camara-just need to improve my skills
Reviews.Author: D. Tuttle "dtuttle"
Reviews.Content: I replaced a Nikon D80 with this, wanting a few more megapixels as I like to make enlargements up to 24x36 or a little bigger.  I liked my Nikon but the reviews I read in magazines seemed to give the edge to this Canon over the corresponding Nikon.  I should state that I'm not a 'photographer' per se.  Meaning, I pretty much shoot in 'Auto' or 'Program' mode all the time with just a few exceptions.  So take that into consideration regarding this review.  What I've found is that the Nikon D80 seemed to do a better job in 'Auto' mode for me.  Obviously, in the hands of someone who has taken the time to learn photography basics, this is a phenomenal camera I'm sure.

Reviews.Title: Canon 60D
Reviews.Author: Mo
Reviews.Content: This camera works well for me in many different shooting situations. Good product. Changing settings is very easy and accessible. The 60D gives the photographer many choices for setting the camera to fit different situations and gives good end results.

Reviews.Title: Good start to a great camera setup!
Reviews.Author: Kevinjhcw
Reviews.Content: I love the 60D....  But it is just a start. You need a whole setup and lenses are way more important than the camera.  The 60D, T3i and T2i are great cameras to start your /videography and photography career off with but make sure to invest more in the lenses.  Check out my video.  [...]  It will show you my entire setup with this camera.  I hope it helps in your buying decision.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding camera, no regrets.
Reviews.Author: Joel
Reviews.Content: I've tested several different cameras, this one was the best with a mix of pro qualities yet still catering to beginner needs.

Reviews.Title: Canon continues to increase value
Reviews.Author: Bruce C. Mcintosh
Reviews.Content: I purchased this primarily for the video capability but having excellent still capability along at the same time is wonderful.  I shoot performances alone with this camera using either my 24-104 or a prime lens depending on the light level and a Canon VIXIA mounted away on another tripod.  The only problems I have found are that recording needs to be manually turned off and back on when you approach the 12 minute max. clip size limit and after about 1 hour of near continuous shooting the temperature warning comes on.  I have only once had it shut down but it makes me nervous.  Adding the external batter module didn't seem to reduce the temperature issue.  I shoot a 2 hour or so performance about every week and it has worked great.

Reviews.Title: 60d canon
Reviews.Author: kio
Reviews.Content: this camera is very easy to use, looks good, it does what i expected. the only problem is I have a wireless remote and when i got the camera it was working fine for couple of days and then it quit working with the remote. I have test and the remote is good maybe something is wrong with the camera. everything other thing it's a good camera.

Reviews.Title: Impressive for new DSLR users
Reviews.Author: Tamer
Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR, I got it with the 18-135 kit... I have done online research, asking many people..etc and decided to go with the 60D... It has everything a beginner need except Full Frame...Full Frame or not to full frame for the first SLR :) ... DO NOT FULL FRAME, SLRs shutters have a life span of 100,000 clicks or so , as a beginner you will be firing allot of pictures just to learn, changing shutter speed, what if the aperture opened more...etc, so u will be wasting your money on buying a bigger sensor that you will waste...now what about the crop factor...honeslty go back a little we are just learning and trust me for beginners you wont feel full frame or APSC frame... remember that lens makes allot of differnce as wellif you decided to live with APSC sensor , the 60D is amazing on the other side ,AMAZING Camera,  very nice handeling, easy software to use and impressive picture quality coming from the Camera with the 18-135 lens...I thought I need to photoshop to have quality pictures , but as of now 3 weeks of usage, pics out of camera are sharp and look so professional... I like it

Reviews.Title: My First DSLR
Reviews.Author: Michael J. Colborn "Savekeeper"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!!!This camera takes awesome pictures and is easy to use.It's been a lot of fun using the camera, learning the functions and experimenting with it.  I've captured some great family portraits, candid shots and even some nice action shots on the soccer field.The software that comes with the camera is great as I am able to download the pictures to my camera and crop them.  I've gotten a lot of nice action shots this way.The kids and I are having a great time with this camera.  Each time I learn how to use one of the functions, I'm teaching it to my kids (ages 16 (twins), 13 & 10).  We're taking lots of digital photos.  Seeing what works and what doesn't and then adjusting our techniques.I tried the HD video for my daughter recital.  The picture quality was good, considering the low light conditions.  I'm looking forward to taking more video in the future and improving my technique.The articulating screen is great.  It's been very convenient when taking odd angled shots.  I'm using it more than I thought I would.So far, I'm very happy with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: Canon EOS 60D
Reviews.Author: Jon
Reviews.Content: The Canon EOS 60D has lived up to all the great reviews so far. It's a great product and it was a great price with fast delivery from Amazon - I don't even waste my time shopping anywhere else these days!

Reviews.Title: My first SLR camera and I am loving it
Reviews.Author: David Jeon
Reviews.Content: This is my first SLR camera and I am loving it.  I was looking into buying 7D but after doing research and found major difference between 60D vs 7D is shutter speed and few others features so I went ahead and bought 60D.  If you're looking for something mid range I believe this is a great investment.  Although others complains 60D body is plastic and takes SD I don't mind @ all.  In addition Like other reviewers and I am father of 2 looking for solid quality pictures of my kids and I don't sell pictures to anyone else.  Hated spending $$$ on studio photos so I went ahead and bought 60D kit but end up selling the lens and bought 24-70mm f/2.8L, Canon EF 85mm f/1.8 lens, and 430EX II flash.  Boy what a difference in terms of quality of pictures.  I realized 60D is not full frame digital SLRs but L series lens open door to whole different world and maybe year or two I will invest on 5D Mark 2 or if 5D 3 releases 2011, I will buy last year model.  Only down side is that its heavy to carry all equipments around but I did buy Canon S95 (our 5th point and shoot camera from Canon) but in terms of quality of pictures I will take 60D anyway.  I recommend to everyone.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Felipe "Felipe"
Reviews.Content: I have upgraded my 550D with this new camera because it has the flexible LCD screen that allows me to better use the HD video filming feature. The 60D is better constructed, and is bigger than the 550D but less than the 7D. I have noticed that the obturator sound is different than the 550D and the 7D, probably because it use different mechanism. This is not a problem at all but the sound is less impressive (its more like a light click). The rest of features gives you a camera that is more close to the 7D. If you feel that the flexible LCD is valuable for you, this camera is a better choice than the 7D (and cheaper). The 18-135 mm IS lens is a VERY GOOD lens. It doesn't has USM but you will never miss it because the DC motor it has is very fast and silent enough. I have compared this lens with my Sigma 18-250mm HSM IS and face to face I have taken similar pictures and I cannot detect any difference. I highly recommend the EOS 60D body with this Sigma lens because this kit gives you more zoom range for all around photography.

Reviews.Title: Canon EOS 60d Problems / issue
Reviews.Author: Mark99
Reviews.Content: An update for canon eos 60d owners suffering the "card write protected" fault.We bought two canon 60d bodies to use as HD video cameras, the first suffered a problem where on screen card write protected fault occurs and now the second body has suffered the same issue just out of warranty.I must say I am not at all impressed with both bodies suffering the same fault, both cameras have been used by separate operators and only for light use and both used different brands of SD cards.It would appear that the SD card reader is the Canon EOs 60d weak area and once this fault occurs when the camera fails to work with any SD card and displays card write protected you are faced with only one option but to pay canon for a fixed price repair leaving you short of £200.canon will only replace the faulty part with the same part that fails and only guarantee the repair for six months ! Which basically means they dont trust it to last more than six months before you have another £200 bill.A camera that needs such a regular repair is not a camera that can be relied upon by anyone other than the occasional shooter.The only solution is to leave the SD card in the camera permanently and hope that usb connector lasts long enough to see you get some use.searching the internet throws up many other users with this fault and leads me to believe the SD card writer fitted in this body is sub quality and prone to failure.As the card can be write protected in the Body, canon could easily release a minor firmware update to instruct the camera to ignore the card write protected fault, instead of stinging owners out who's warranties have expired £200 a time for a manufacturing fault.The 60d is a great camera, until it breaks ! then you own a door step.I shall not be repairing either body and will sell them both for spares and buy a SLR for HD video from another maker that does not break !

Reviews.Title: Canon's mediocre quality control
Reviews.Author: Florin
Reviews.Content: This is my second Canon DSLR camera that comes with defective CMOS sensor pixels out of the box. The first was a Canon 450D, purchased in Europe.Yes, it's a great camera and I would still get a replacement but checking for dead pixels on the SENSOR should be a basic quality control on a camera that praises itself to be made in Japan.Moreover, not having any local repair shop in NYC is unacceptable for a company at this level. When I called their customer support they said I should send it to some remote location.This means wasted time on a product many people expect to use straight away, maybe even on an upcoming holiday.Such issues make me distrust this company a lot, if i had to go into dslr photography I'd chose Nikon straight away.If you want to make sure the product is ok and don't want any surprises, buy it from a local store and check it thoroughly![UPDATE JAN 2011]Allright, so I could not resist buying a second copy of the camera from a retail store in Washington DC where I got to test it on the spot for obvious failures.It would be cool if someone made a checklist of things to look for when testing a camera in the store, on the spot.For me, a good, quick test for dead pixels would be to switch on live view with the lens cap on. Any dead pixels will show up on the black screen, unless dead pixels appear black as well in which case, test on a white sheet of paper.Luckily this one was just fine and 3 months after having bought it i can say i'm extremely happy with it.I've recently compared it to my 450D which I haven't used since and it really feels a lot better (of course that's what new models appear for) but really, the grip is superb, the screen is vibrant and of great detail not to mention articulated (which I frequently use).Another thing that's awsome is the ability to remote trigger flashes. It even works with TTL for canon flashes which saves you from spending money on transmitters. For any strobist enthusiast it's a great feature!I've had one problem though, which was easily fixed and seems to plague more canon models. The popup flash wouldn't raise after an external flash was mounted because a little metal cling got stuck on the external flash sensor in the hotshoe.Overall, I think it's a great camera that really feels way better than the rebel series, just make sure you get a good copy!

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera !
Reviews.Content: Hi,I was looking for a camera that could help me to get a good clips for a reasonable price, because I'm learning visual effects, and I need to capture my own videos to learn better. I can start with any HD camcorder, but if I'm going to be a professional in this business as I wish, then I'm going to work with a professional camera.This Canon 60d was the answer and more than perfect for me. I mean with a appropriate lens, a good angle and a dolly or a tripod dolly combined with a good story and an actor, you can easily match any Hollywood movie out there.This camera can rock your world!.The only thing that make me rate it 4 stars is the ISO thing. I mean you need a great lighting to have a good picture at night or at dark places in general, just to get rid of the Grain it the clip. I was hoping to buy a Nikon D3S, but come on, there are like $2k difference in price between these two, just for this ISO issue ??? Besides, Canon 60d can capture 60fps in 1280x720, I just tested it and it was AMAZING!From the day you buy this camera, you just need to focus on lenses and have at least 3 of them for different purposes, because Canon 60d can handle any video or picture just like the way any other costly camera can do.It took me a month of seeking and thousands of reviews until I finally convinced that this is what I'm looking for.I may make a video review later.I really can't find any words to thank Canon for making my dream came true.

Reviews.Title: Great, but you should know...
Reviews.Author: Jennifer C. Hofstetter "Jen Hofstetter Photog...
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera last week and it's awesome.  Picture quality is great, color is great, it's fast.  I've been using the Canon Rebel XT/350D, but I wanted to upgrade to something better.  I'm a budding professional photographer, but my business hasn't really picked up yet, so this is a great economic choice for an upgrade.Things to keep in mind before purchasing:1. Does not use CompactFlash memory cards like most other Canon models right now;2. Camera Raw is not compatible with Photoshop CS4 or older;3. *MAC USERS* CameraRaw files are NOT compatible with OSX 10.5 or whatever Leopard is.  There is an update you can download from Apple, but it only works if you have and older version of Aperture or iPhoto 8.  My Mac is from 2007, so I have an older version of iPhoto and there is no update for that.  You can purchase a Snow Leopard upgrade for $30.00, but I haven't done that yet, and I don't know if that will upgrade my iLife programs as well, making Camera Raw files readable.These are things I wish I'd known before I purchased the camera.  Canon says it's compatible with OSX 10.5, and the JPEG files are, but they don't advertise that CR files require OSX 10.6, as well as the newest version of PS.  :/  I'm a little frustrated since I just laid out a grand, and now I'll have to spend another $250 to upgrade everything else.  Add that to the new memory cards I need to buy (which I knew about, so no mark against that), and I might as well have bought the 7D.But, if you know all of this going in and don't mind it, it's a really great camera.  I love the swivel LCD screen.  I don't really like the fun creative functions too much, as the effects can be created with much better quality using PS, but a novice user might enjoy them.Layout wise, it's very clean and intuitive.  The menu is easy to navigate, the navigation buttons and wheels are great.  Personally, I don't like that the main dial is always locked, but I can see why it's a plus for most people.  AF is efficient, no complaints there.  I notice a LOT of noise at higher ISOs with basic editing, which I had read wasn't a problem, so I'm guessing that it's probably incorrect settings on my end, or the fact that I can't edit RAW yet.  We'll see.Aside from the additional costs of upgrading my computer and software, it's a 1000x improvement over my old Rebel.

Reviews.Title: Great camera - but screen is way to sensitive!!
Reviews.Author: Gal
Reviews.Content: It is not a review about the camera as a whole but more of a complaint.The camera, as a DSLR , is amazing. Quality is great and it's fast,intuitive,easy to use and loaded with features.My problem is I had a 40D for 6 years which didn't have an articulating screen and it barely had a scratch on the LCD.I had the 60D for two days and the screen, although high quality, is totally scratches! I'm not talking about deep scratches from walls, metals etc.. I'm talking about those shallow but very annoying scratches. It's just a magnet for them scratches. I admit, I did not close the articulating screen all the time and I did walk with it open (flipped backwards). It does not change the fact the it is full of scratches from my SHIRT and my JEANS.I am pleased with the camera but it just annoys me the after only 2 days the LCD is fully scratched.. I assumed that if my 40D lasted so well (without screen protector)..I could live few days without a screen protector with my new 60D. I was wrong, now it drives me crazy.I know that I can send it to Canon for a not-too-expensive screen cover replacement but I don't live in the US and here it's not as easy to do.Another complaints worth mentioning:  Removing of the joystick was a mistake and the soft button ,that aren't giving any feedback, are not amazing..Apply a screen protector or close the flipped screen after every use!!

Overall I'll give it 4 1/2 stars......

Reviews.Title: A great mid-range camera with lots of bells and whistles
Reviews.Author: Tooncesmom
Reviews.Content: I purchased a Canon EOS 60D as an upgrade for an older 10D model. I chose the 60D because it is the latest model that still uses the same lenses that fit the 10D, and since I had two rather pricey ones, the Canon Zoom Lens EF 28-135mm and a 300mm lens, I wanted a camera body where these lenses could be used. (The 60D is compatible with all EF and EF-S lenses.)Key Features:18 megapixel (The 18 megapixel 60D is an amazing camera; I'm still discovering the differences), some of which are listed below.ISO - 100 - 6400 (expandable to 12,800)5.3 fps (frames per second) for ultra-rapid-fire shooting (58 large pegs, 16 RAW)Dual-layer metering systemAudio Video that can be set to automatic or manual with noise reduction filterVideo recording in HD mode with manual exposure controlIn-Camera RAW developmentSubject Mode Ambiance Selection (standard, soft, warm, intense, cool, etc.)Multi-control dial - offers a wide range of color variations (ambiances) that works much like Photoshop, but within the camera.In-Camera conversion - lets the user go from RAW to jpeg and apply new creative filters.In-Camera creation of special effects - this one works in RAW but not jpeg.The LCD Panel is a 3-inch screen that can flip out and be set at various angles.Movie recording capability.I've found that using the long-range lens in, for example, bird photography, the 18 megapixels give an enormous advantage for cropped photos. With the 10D, distance shots cropped were always a bit fuzzy, but the 60D keeps them in sharp focus.I am not a professional photographer and the 60D offers much more than I will ever use, but I like the autofocus, love the sharp images when cropping distance shots and love the ability to convert from RAW to jpeg within the camera. I would have preferred that Canon stuck with the magnesium alloy body rather than switch to plastic, however, the plastic body is considerably lighter than my 10D and seems sturdy enough for anything I'll put it through. I'm extremely pleased with this camera and give it five stars. Because other reviewers have commented at length about the more technical aspects, I decided to review what I have personally used and found noteworthy.

Reviews.Title: a little disappointed about the video function
Reviews.Author: sharp pencil
Reviews.Content: I bought the 60D because I wanted a descent DSLR that is equally good in taking photos and video. After hours and hours of research I went for the 60 because all reviews said if you want both that's it.well, the photos come out as expected even though it takes a while of digging through all the settings before finding what works best from all the menu options if you want the camera to do certain things.Where I'm disappointed is with the video function. Sure it does HD and if you focus before you start recording the quality comes out as promised. But forget about focused videos if you want to zoom or change distance to the object while filming. It doesn't autofocus!!! You can press the shutter release half way to refocus but the autofocus struggles to regain focus for a few seconds and is noisy. And of course it records this pitiful attempt.I was hoping to replace my 8y old Panasonic miniDV video camera with this camera plus my failing point&shoot; without having to buy a still camera & a video camera again but I guess this is not it to do so. Since the T2 and T3 have the same photo quality you may go for these cheaper models (with the same major components) and buy a dedicated video camera for the savings that will do a better job than the 60D.

Reviews.Title: Do NOT buy CANON. REPAIR RIPOFF FOR THE 60D
Reviews.Author: Frequent traveller
Reviews.Content: As with many 60D cameras,mine also experience the common problem of the rubber covers of the body ("handles") peeling off from the camera in multiple places, which is a textbook case of a manufacturing defect.I sent it to Canon's Newport News VA repair facility, and they billed me for $200. which they said is the "standard repair fee".The replacement parts bought from Canon, by the way, cost $14. and it takes 2-3 minutes to replace them, as I found out later. Yet, I was charged $200 because that is Canon's "policy" which, I suppose must be titled, "Rip the customer off" policy.When I called that repair center to complain, a supervisor lied to me on a recorded conversation (legal in Virginia), and asserted that this is not a common problem at all. In fact it is a very problem on 60D cameras that has been widely reported on, among others, [...] (owned by Amazon).Canon is not the only game in town.

Reviews.Title: Upgrade?
Reviews.Author: Brian Lange.
Reviews.Content: There are already 900+ reviews for this outdated model so there's not much point but here's a quickie:This was an upgrade for me.  With all the new Canon's that have come out, this one with lens was actually cheaper for me than when I bought my 30d years ago (also when the newer models were released)  Unless you are a hardcore professional (an actual professional) then this is more than you can ask for.  It's the first SLR I've owned that also shoots video.  It looks good and will do the trick for basic shooting... but if you really want to do actual shooting, then you should buy a camera that's primary function is video and not photo.  Not photo then video.  For photographers, this is a terrific buy!!The menu and interface on the back is different and will take a bit of getting used to from previous models, but you get accustomed to them quickly.  If this is your first SLR then definitely get this because of the great price.  Shelling out huge bucks for the latest model is overkill and unnecessary.

Reviews.Title: LOVE IT!!
Reviews.Author: PandaMolanda
Reviews.Content: This is my very first DSLR to own (I used a Canon 20D before). I've had it for 7 months now and it has been fabulous! It is a great starter camera for beginning, but serious, photographers. It is also $100 cheaper buying from amazon compared to the Canon website.One of my favorite features is the rotating screen. It makes it so much easier when doing self portraits or getting a really low or high angle shots. The screen for the camera is really great quality too!I would recommend buying the body only and getting a different lens, other than the one that generally comes with the camera. I bought the Canon 50mm 1.8 lens, which is a great starter lens and is only about $120. Very cheap for a lens!The ONLY downside to the camera is that while using the video recorder, the camera tends to get a little hot. It will even tell you that in the instruction manual. This really only happens when you record for long periods of time. If you record for over 30 minutes, the camera usually gets a little warm. I think it's so awesome that Canon put an HD video recorder on a DSLR, but there's definitely room for improvement in the future! If you plan on using this soley for video, I would recommend getting an actual video camera.The liveview mode was a little disappointing too because it takes longer than usual for the camera to focus. I was really excited about this feature but definitely let down in the end. I think this is another one of those camera features that needs improvement in the future!I definitely wouldn't let any negative sides of the 60D keep you from purchasing it! I love my camera to death and don't have ANY regrets about buying it. Buy it!

Reviews.Title: Here's the bottom line
Reviews.Content: This camera is excellent for anyone who has experience with DSLR's. The features are awesome.  If your only concern is to take good IQ pictures and you don't care much about the other advanced pictures, you can do with the Canon XS, XSI, and T1i. All these cameras are capable of taking great IQ pics depending, of course, if you know how to get the correct settings although Manual and P mode can also take great pics.My last camera was a canon T1i, and I loved it. The reasons I bought the 60D are follows:1. Vari angle LCD. I find this feature extremely helpful. I can take pictures from different angle with ease2. Faster FPS at 5.3. I watch college football and love to take action pics3. It has more features than the T1i and the AF system is fasterI don't really care about the pixel count as I hardly print my pictures. I almost always store the pics on my computer and post them on facebook or flickr. A 6 megapixel should do even for printing up  to 8 1/2 by 11. If you are planning to print pictures larger than that, it's the only time you would need higher pixel cameras, or if you plan to crop your pics so you would not lose any details.For the typical consumer whose only goal is to take nice pictures without having to worry about shutter lag, any of the canon, pentax, nikon (don't like sony) have the potential to take great pictures.If you are a prosumer, you can't go wrong with the 50D, 60D, or 7D. All these three cameras are great. It's all about your skill level and the features you prefer. I was going to get the Nikon D7000 as it has better features than the 60D, not to mention it is also weather sealed, but I really like the articulating screen of Canon that's why I chose it.

Reviews.Title: Good camera, somewhat dated
Reviews.Author: Andi C Bair
Reviews.Content: Canon EOS 60D is a somewhat earlier version DSLR. Let me use my usual disclaimer, and admit that with so many good cameras around, it is more about what mix of traits or features you are looking for.On that note, the camera's trait mix is as follows. It has an 18 megapixels resolution. Most importantly, the sensor size is APS-C. That's just one step below 35mm Full frame.It has an optical viewfinder, which works through a pentaprism. The purists would argue this is the way it was supposed to be- that is, with minimal electronic intervention. As in most Canon DSLRs, it has a Dioptric adjustment to make it easy for people with glasses to use the viewfinder. Also, you can preview depth of field. The dust deletion mechanism includes a software adjustment for removing/modifying the affected pixels, self-cleaning sensor, and manual cleaning.The ISO rating is 12,800 and it works fairly true to specifications. The video is a Full HD. The camera gives you the option to control the exposure and focus manually, has an external flash option, and does RAW processing. You would need the external flash at least for portraits. The LCD screen is very clear with a whopping 1,040,000 resolution. It can be tilted for easy viewing in awkward situations. The sustainable burst rate- for fast action- is 5.3 frames per second. The camera body weighs 755 grams.Compared to the Canon T5i, 60D has an older processor. It has the Digic 4; T5i has Digic 5. It is also heavier, has lower ISO rating, and the LCD screen does not have the touch features.On the other hand, the 60D has a more advanced autofocus system than the T5i and lower-end EOS cameras. Peripheral focus is an option, whereas with T5i, if a moving object goes out of the central area, it does not get zeroed in. 60D also has a more durable body with environmental seals for extended rugged use. It has the touch and feel of a professional camera.A good camera, but its traits are a bit dated for its category.
